data.title: Photo Gallery: Past Nobel Peace Prize Winners
data.meta_description: The most coveted of honors: The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded annually to the person who has devoted the most to the pursuit of peace and fraternity between nations. Here are the prize winners since 1990. Der mit zehn Millionen schwedischen Kronen dotierte Preis (etwa eine Million Euro) ging an Personen, die sich für eine friedlichere Welt einsetzen. Die Preisträger seit 1990 auf SPIEGEL ONLINE.
data.text:
The ex-president of Finland, Martti Ahtisaari, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2008. He successfully led peace negotiations between the Free Aceh Movement and the Indonesian government -- a feat which is considered to be his greatest.

Former American Vice President Al Gore was awarded the Nobel Prize alongside the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) "for their efforts to build up and disseminate greater knowledge about man-made climate change."

Mohammed Yunus founded the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh and gave microcredit loans to poor entrepreneurs. In 2006, Yunus and the bank were jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for their efforts to create economic and social development from below."

The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and its director general, Mohamed ElBaradei, were jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2005 "for their efforts to prevent nuclear energy from being used for military purposes and to ensure that nuclear energy for peaceful purposes is used in the safest possible way."

Opposition activist Wangari Maathai, the first woman in Kenya to hold a doctorate, was awarded the prize in 2004 for her contribution to sustainable development, democracy and peace."

In 2003, Shirin Ebadi became the first Iranian to recieve the prize. The human rights activist was put on trial for two years and was prohibited from working in Iran. She was praised by the Nobel Committee for her "significant and pioneering efforts for democracy and human rights."

Former US President Jimmy Carter earned the prize in 2002 for his work "to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, to advance democracy and human rights and to promote economic and social development." Since leaving office, Carter has been active with the non-profit organization Habitat for Humanity, which builds homes for the needy.

In 2001 the Nobel Committee chose the United Nations as led by Kofi Annan "for their work for a better organized and more peaceful world."

Former South Korean President Kim Dae Jung was awarded the prize "for his work for democracy and human rights in South Korea and in East Asia in general, and for peace and reconciliation with North Korea in particular."

Workers with the non-governmental organization Médecins Sans Frontières, or Doctors Without Borders, in Kabul, Afghanistan. The organization was awarded the prize in 1999 in recognition of its members' continuous effort to provide medical care in acute crises.

After nearly 30 years of conflict in Northern ireland, John Hume of the Social Democratic and Labour Party (on the right) and former First Minister of Northern Ireland David Trimble were able to come to a compromise. They were awarded the prize in 1998 "for their efforts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict in Northern Ireland."

Jody Williams and the International Campaign to Ban Landmines were awarded the prize in 1997 "for their work for the banning and clearing of anti-personnel mines."

The President of East Timor, José Ramos-Horta (pictured), was awarded the prize in 1996 alongside Carlos Filipe Ximenes Belo. The committee commended "their work towards a just and peaceful solution to the conflict in East Timor."

The founder of the Pugwash movement, British physician Joseph Rotblat (on the right) and the Pugwash Conferences on Science and World Affairs were given the award in 1995 "for their efforts to diminish the part played by nuclear arms in international politics and, in the longer run, to eliminate such arms."

Nelson Mandela was awarded the prize in 1993 alongside Frederik Willem de Klerk "for their work for the peaceful termination of the apartheid regime, and for laying the foundations for a new democratic South Africa."

Rigoberta Menchu has devoted her life to publicizing the plight of Guatemala's indigenous peoples during and after the Guatemalan Civil War. She was commended "(for) her work for social justice and ethno-cultural reconciliation based on respect for the rights of indigenous peoples".
